prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my girlfriend she doesn’t need to make plans every time I want to game?
My girlfriend and I have been living together for 4 months now. We’ve been together for 3 years, and I’ve loved every minute of it and we absolutely adore each other.

When we first got together I gave up a lot of my free time for dates and other couple things like that. 

We would spend the night together sometimes. But when we would go home alone, to our respective houses. I would use that time to get my game time in.

Now flash forward, we live together and are obviously spending more time together. 

It all started a few weeks ago after work, when my buddy messaged me and asked me to get on and play Apex Legends, I say yeah, and tell my girlfriend I’m gonna play some games if she doesn’t mind. Up until that point we only used my Xbox as an entertainment system ( think Hulu, YouTube and Netflix.) 

I had previously taken a pretty long break from games and I didn’t expect this to be her reaction.

She said, it’s not fair for me to play games because she has nothing else to do while we play. I said, well you can watch me play jokingly, I thought she was kidding at first, but then she continued and said if I wanna make plans then to let her know so she can be busy while I’m busy. She also said she missed me. I told her we could have time for just us when I was done playing, and that it wasn’t a “plan.” I’m not going anywhere, I’ll be right here. I even told her we could talk while I played. But she didn’t want to have any of it. She just went to her sisters house for a few hours, and I proceeded to get some dubs.

Then, it became an argument we had 2-3 times. I even gave her advanced notice on an occasion or two but If she failed to make her plan she blamed it on me. So I told her ‘she didn’t need to go out every time, I’m busy. Just relax and chill on your phone or use my laptop.’ 

She’s the kinda girl who wants constant attention and I am fine with that, but I also want to chill with my friends online and play. 

AITA?

Tl;dr Girlfriend wants me to preplan my gaming time so she can make plans to go out. I said she doesn’t need to go out just because I wanna play games.
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the author is in the wrong. The situation is about the author's girlfriend wanting him to plan his gaming time so she can make her own plans, but he's telling her she doesn't need to go out every time he plays.

First, I need to understand both sides. The author mentions that they've been together for 3 years and living together for 4 months. They used to have separate time where he would game, but now that they live together, the girlfriend feels that when he plays, she has nothing to do. She wants him to plan his gaming so she can make her own plans. The author argues that she doesn't have to leave every time and can just relax on her phone or use the laptop. 

The key points here are communication and expectations. When they first got together, he gave up some free time for dates, but now with living together, there's a shift in dynamics. The girlfriend's issue is that when he's gaming, she wants to have something to do, which she interprets as needing to make plans. The author thinks she's overreacting and that she can just relax.

The question is whether the author is wrong. From a relationship perspective, it's important for both partners to feel valued and heard. The author's initial approach was to let her know when he wants to play, but she's not satisfied and feels neglected. The author might not see his gaming as a problem, but his partner's feelings are valid. 

The author's response when she expressed her feelings was dismissive. Saying she can just relax on her phone might not address her need for personal time or activities. The girlfriend might feel that her needs are being ignored, especially if she's used to having his attention. The author's argument that he's not going anywhere and they can talk while he plays might not be enough for her. 

In relationships, it's crucial to meet in the middle. The author could be in the wrong if he's not acknowledging her feelings and not compromising. However, he's also expressing his need to have personal time with friends. The issue is communication and finding a balance. 

The author's girlfriend might need more attention, and the author's gaming time is a point of tension. The author's response was to tell her she doesn't have to make plans, but maybe he should have discussed it more to find a solution that works for both. 

So, considering both sides, the author might be partially at fault for not fully addressing her feelings and not finding a compromise. However, it's also about mutual understanding. The answer depends on whether the author's actions are dismissive of his partner's valid concerns. 

In this case, since the girlfriend is expressing her needs and the author is not meeting them halfway, the author could be in the wrong. But it's not entirely his fault either. However, based on the scenario, the answer is likely A (Yes) because he's not adequately considering her perspective and needs.
